awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Evolving the mammalian forelimb: modeling musculoskeletal transformation in the forerunners of mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
A unique feature of mammals is their many different forelimb shapes and functions, including highly distinct forelimbs for running, climbing, digging, swimming, and flying. No other group of animals has such diverse forelimbs, and the flexibility of mammal forelimbs seems to be a key reason for the group's success. The first mammal relatives found in the fossil record are over 300 million years old, and are a striking contrast to living mammals: their forelimbs show a very limited range of shapes and functions. How did the evolutionarily-flexible forelimbs of mammals evolve from such seemingly constrained ancestors, and did changes to the forelimb increase the ability of mammals to explore new ways of life? This research project will use state-of-the-art techniques, and extensive data from fossils and modern animals, to reconstruct forelimb structure and function in ancient mammal relatives, and to test whether changes to the forelimb correlate with increases in their ecological diversity. The results will deepen our understanding of the evolution of a quintessential characteristic of mammals, and its role in the evolution of animals as distinct as bats, moles, whales, horses, and humans. Dissemination of the research will occur through a series of educational online videos produced by the award-winning YouTube Channel "The Brain Scoop". The series will include three episodes describing different stages of the research, and two episodes that describe the results and their significance. Audience responses to the videos will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of online videos as a tool for science education.

Modern mammals display remarkable ecomorphological diversity, which is underpinned by exaptation of the forelimb to serve novel functions (e.g. flying, running, swimming, and digging). In contrast, the ancestors of mammals - the non-mammalian synapsids - are generalized terrestrial tetrapods with seemingly limited ecological scope. The mammalian-style forelimb, including a fully mobile scapula, ventrally oriented ball-and-socket shoulder joint, and "upright" limb posture and movement, is the result of a profound reorganization of the ancestral synapsid musculoskeletal system. Drawing from the extensive synapsid fossil record, this project integrates a diverse set of methodological techniques to pinpoint how morphofunctional transformation of the forelimb influenced the tempo and mode of phenotypic evolution of the synapsid clade. Rigorous morphometric analyses will quantify shape disparity in forelimb skeletal elements and identify major shifts in morphology. Cutting-edge biomechanical analyses will correlate morphological shifts with functional transformation. And, advanced phylogenetic modeling techniques will determine whether shifts in morphology and function resulted in increases in diversification rates. Key products include a new comprehensive metatree of Synapsida, an extensive geometric morphometric dataset, and 3D musculoskeletal models of ten taxa at phylogenetically informative stages of synapsid evolution. Combined, this project will build a robust comparative framework to quantify musculoskeletal transformations in extinct animals and provide a unique evolutionary perspective on an integrated anatomical module of significant adaptive value.

por.por_cntn:
Mammals are unique for having hair, acute hearing, precise chewing of their food, and the ability to produce milk. But mammals are also remarkable for their capacity to move in many different ways, from flying and digging to swimming and running, a feature supported by their highly versatile forelimb structure. These diverse means of locomotion have helped mammals to colonize every continent, and every ocean, where they can be found in an extraordinary array of habitats. This stands in stark contrast to the extinct relatives of mammals who appear to have been limited in how they moved, could only engage in a restricted set of behaviors, and whose forelimbs were constrained to a small range of shapes. So, how did the adaptable forelimbs of mammals evolve and what was their role in the evolution of animals as distinct as bats, moles, whales, horses, and humans? 

To address this fundamental question, hundreds of fossils were examined from museum collections around the world. Three dimensional digital replicas were made using various scanning techniques - X-rays, lasers, photographs - and the anatomy of all the bones and muscles that make up the forelimb was determined through comparison with living animals. The data were then studied to trace how forelimb function changed across geological time and as new lineages emerged with different combinations of evolutionary attributes. Novel analytical methods were devised to 1) estimate the motions of the forelimb and identify what poses each animal could achieve in life, and 2) statistically establish how forelimb form and function changed along the mammal evolutionary tree, from 300 million years ago to the present day. 

When comparing living animals with different forelimb anatomies, postures and modes of locomotion, there were clear differences in form and function between groups. Modern mammals have upright forelimb postures, where the elbow points backwards, and their muscles are most effective at pulling the limb up and back to propel themselves forward during walking.  In contrast, reptiles, like lizards and crocodiles, have sprawling forelimb postures, with their elbows pointing out to the side. Their muscles are most effective at pulling the limb down, to maintain stable contact with the ground. The data from these living animals provide an essential framework for interpreting fossil specimens, many of which had forelimb postures similar to reptiles, but had less mobile joints and different muscle leverage.

The earliest mammal ancestors had forelimb anatomies quite different from any living and extinct animals and it was from this distinct starting point that the mammalian forelimb then evolved. While the structure of the forelimb changed dramatically over the course of mammalian evolution - with bones and joints changing in shape and orientation - most extinct species explored a limited set of forelimb functions, postures and behaviors as compared to modern-day mammals. The mammal-type forelimb, with its full complement of functional abilities, appears to have arisen late in the evolutionary history of mammals, probably close to the origin of therians, which includes marsupial (e.g., kangaroos, possums) and placental (e.g., bears, humans) mammals. While some extinct species did fill different niches, the full array of ecological diversity seen in mammals today was not realized for hundreds of millions of years. 

The research was disseminated to a broad audience through an online video entitled How Shoulders Took Over the World was developed in collaboration with SciShow and presented by award winning science communicator Emily Graslie: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IxPhaOHF3ko&t=2s. SciShow is a collection of YouTube channels that focuses on science news and the series has been consistently releasing new material since it was created in 2012. The episode, which focused on the role the forelimb played in the evolutionary success of mammals, has been viewed over 260,000 times since its release in summer of 2022 and received nearly 500 comments and thousands of interactions. In addition, the research was disseminated to local communities through various outreach events hosted by the Harvard Museum of Natural History (e.g., National Fossil Day).
